Shape: A medium-sized sparrow with a large, round head, conical seed-eating bill, and a medium length tail.
Compared Size: Larger than a Blue-gray Gnatcatcher, smaller than a Horned Lark.

description: Most striking feature is the face pattern: neat gray bordered by 2 strong white stripes and a black triangular throat patch. Upperparts are grayish brown and the underparts are a paler mix of cream and white. The tail is dark with white spots on the corners. Juveniles look like adults but lack the black throat patch and have faint streaks above and below.
Hops on the ground, pecking for seeds and insects, and makes short low flights between shrubs. Often perches in trees and shrubs giving quiet calls.
Dry scrubby areas, desert scrub, canyons, and washes.
